desc: This course covers more advanced concepts of JAX-RS. You will learn some important concepts related to resource life cycle, authentication and client APIs. You will also implement framework extensions like converters, message readers and writers.
name: Advanced JAX-RS
objectives: Bootstrapping JAX-RS applications with Application class
Building a REST API client in Java using JAX-RS

1.unitDescription: Learn how to setup a JAX-RS application in an environment-agnostic way using the Application class. Deploy a REST API web application on Tomcat without a servlet.xml.

lessons.description: Welcome to the course! This video provide a quick introduction to the topics that will be covered in this course.

lessons.title: Tomcat Setup

lessons.description: We'll now create a new Maven web application and setup pom.xml to pull in the dependencies we need for a JAX-RS application.
lessons.title: Setting Up Pom xml

lessons.description: Complete the application by bootstrapping JAX-RS using the built-in Application class.
lessons.title: Setting up a JAX RS application

lessons.description: In this lesson, we'll understand what the Application class is and how it sets up the JAX-RS application and the necessary resource classes.
lessons.title: The Application Class

lessons.title: The Application Class Quiz

quizContent.question: What is the JAX-RS class that you need to extend in order to configure your REST application?

answers.content: Servlets are slow in execution performance
Servlet technology is outdated, and it's better to use the newer Application class
The servlet approach restricts you to a servlet container. The Application class is deployment-agnostic.

quizContent.question: Why would we prefer to use the Application class instead of a servlet class to bootstrap a JAX-RS application?

answers.content: Create a class with the name Application and make it available in the class path
Create a sub-class of the abstract Application class and make it available in the class path
Create an implementation of the Application interface and implement all the methods of the interface
Annotate your resource classes with the @Application annotation
